question: WHAT IS RSA ENCRYPTION?
search_query: RSA encryption WHAT IS RSA ENCRYPTION WHAT IS RSA ENCRYPTION?

documents.content: Quantum-Computing and the Security Challenge‚Ä¢Quantum computers threaten RSA, ECC, and DH schemes (Shor‚Äôs and Grover‚Äôs algorithms). Once large-scale quantum computers are built, they will be capable of breaking most exis1ng public-key cryptosystems.‚Ä¢This poses a serious threat to the conÔ¨Åden1ality and integrity of Internet communica1ons.

Industry Migration Status‚Ä¢OpenSSLbegan introducing post-quantum cryptography algorithms starting with version 3.0, providing support for schemes such as Kyberand Dilithium.‚Ä¢OpenSSH (Key Exchange) has rapidly moved to adopt NIST-standardized Post-Quantum Key Exchange (PQC KEX) to secure remote access protocols in version 9.9.‚Ä¢The Hybrid Approach combines a classical algorithm with a PQC algorithm for defense-in-depth:‚Ä¢Mechanism:mlkem768x25519-sha256‚Ä¢Classical: X25519 (Traditional ECDH)‚Ä¢PQC: ML-KEM (Kyber)‚Ä¢In version 10.0, this hybrid method was made the defaultkey exchange mechanism.

Performance on Digital Signature‚Ä¢The performance of PQC algorithms is so poor that their practical deployment often encounters resistance from vendors.‚Ä¢Transition challenges:‚Ä¢Larger key sizes, slower performance‚Ä¢Integration into TLS, VPNs, IoT devices‚Ä¢However, growing security demands compel continued exploration and development of these algorithms.‚Ä¢Harvest-Now-Decrypt-Later
traditional algorithms (
‚ùå), 
‚úÖ standardized, 
üìù soon-to-be standardized, or 
ü§î still candidateshttps://blog.cloudflare.com/another-look-at-pq-signatures/

The Learning With Errors (LWE) ProblemLWE can be thought of as a ‚Äúnoisy system of linear equations‚Äùthat‚Äôs hard to solve.Suppose you are given a set of linear equations:If there‚Äôs no noise, solving for s (the secret vector) is easy ‚Äìjust linear algebra.But in LWE, we add small random noise to each equation:Where A is known matrix (public), s is secret vector (unknown), e is small random ‚Äúerror‚Äù vector (noise), q is a modulus (a large prime or power of 2)  ‚Ä¢Given,only(A,b),itbecomescomputationallyinfeasibletorecovers‚ÄìNP-hard   ‚Ä¢While LWE is secure, it‚Äôs computationally heavy‚Äîoperations on large matrices and vectors are expensive.

Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC)‚Ä¢Goal:Develop cryptographic systems secure against both quantum and classical attacks.‚Ä¢Must interoperate with existing protocols and networksto ensure a smooth transition.‚Ä¢Be executable on all devices (e.g.classical computers, mobile phone, sensors). This is the difference between PQC and the separate field of quantum cryptography. ‚Ä¢PQC is a proactive defense‚Äîanticipating quantum capabilities before they arrive.

Ring-LWE (R-LWE) ‚ÄîThe Optimized VersionRing-LWEis a more efficient variantthat replaces vectors and matrices with polynomials.Wherea(x),s(x),e(x)arepolynomials withsmallinteger coefficients. f(x) is a fixed modulus polynomial (e.g.ùë•!+ 1). ‚Ä¢Alloperationsarepolynomialarithmetic,whichcanbecomputedefficientlyusingfastFourier transforms (FFT). ‚Ä¢Application: 1. CRYSTALS-Kyber(encryption/ key exchange)2. CRYSTALS-Dilithium(digital signature)

CRYSTALS-KyberCryptography‚Ä¢Let                                      be a ring
CRYSTALS-Kyber, Martin Strand, Nov. 2023, https://www.uio.no/studier/emner/matnat/its/TEK4500/h23/lectures/lecture-14---crystals-kyber-(guest-lecture-martin-strand).pdf

Reading Materials‚Ä¢PQCrypto: post-quantum cryptography conference series. https://pqcrypto.org/conferences.html‚Ä¢Chen, Lily, et al.Report on post-quantum cryptography. Vol. 12. Gaithersburg, MD, USA: US Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ir/2016/NIST.IR.8105.pdf?ref=suddo.de‚Ä¢FIPS 203‚Äì205 Documents ‚Äìcsrc.nist.gov‚Ä¢Joseph, David, et al. "Transitioning organizations to post-quantum cryptography."Nature605.7909 (2022): 237-243.https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-04623-2‚Ä¢A. Aydeger, etc. ‚ÄúTowards a Quantum-Resilient Future: Strategies for Transitioning to Post-Quantum Cryptography‚Äù,2024 https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=10741441

Open-Source PQC Repository‚Ä¢The Open Quantum Safe (OQS)project, specifically its liboqslibrary, is a core force in the open-source PQC space. It is now part of the Linux Foundation's Post-Quantum Cryptography Alliance (PQCA).‚Ä¢open-quantum-safe/liboqs. https://openquantumsafe.org/‚Ä¢liboqsintegrates various quantum-resistant Key-Encapsulation Mechanisms (KEMs)and digital signature algorithms. It supports the algorithms selected by NIST, such as ML-KEM (Kyber), ML-DSA (Dilithium), SLH-DSA (SPHINCS+), and Falcon. Furthermore, it includes candidate algorithms from the NIST Fourth Round evaluation, as well as other promising schemes.‚Ä¢liboqsprovides a unified APIinterface, making it easy for developers to switch between different algorithms. The project also includes a test toolsetand performance benchmarkingprograms, along with wrappers for multiple programming languages (e.g., Java, Python, Rust, Go) and integration solutions for common applications like OpenSSL.

NIST PQC Standards ‚Ä¢PQC algorithms that NIST has finalized for standardization (as of Aug. 2024) include:‚Ä¢FIPS 203 ML-KEM:Module-Lattice-Based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism Standard -Derived from CRYSTALS-Kyber‚Ä¢FIPS 204 ML-DSA:Module-Lattice-Based Digital Signature Standard -Derived from CRYSTALS-Dilithium‚Ä¢FIPS 205 SLH-DSA:Stateless Hash-Based Digital Signature Standard -Derived from SPHINCS+

LaCce-BasedPost Quantum Cryptography‚Ä¢A latticeis a regular grid of points in multi-dimensional space, defined by integer combinations of basis vectors (linear independent, no need orthogonal).‚Ä¢Core Hard Problems (hard for both classical and quantum computers)‚Ä¢Shortest Vector Problem (SVP):Find the shortest nonzero vector in a lattice ‚Äîextremely hard in high dimensions.‚Ä¢Closest Vector Problem (CVP):Given a random point, find the closest lattice point ‚Äîalso very hard.‚Ä¢Learning With Errors (LWE) / Ring-LWE Problem:Recover a hidden vector from noisy linear equations ‚Äîbelieved to be hard even for quantum computers.‚Ä¢Most modern lattice-based cryptosystems are built on LWE or Ring-LWE.

PQC algorithms familiesFamilyCore Math IdeaExample AlgorithmsAnalogy / Teaching AidLattice-basedHardness of finding short vectors in high-dimensional latticesKyber, Dilithium, NTRU‚ÄúFinding the shortest straw in a 1000D haystack‚ÄùCode-basedError correction in random linear codesClassic McEliece‚ÄúGuessing errors in noisy messages‚ÄùMultivariateSolving nonlinear polynomial equationsRainbow, GeMSS‚ÄúJigsaw puzzles of equations‚ÄùHash-basedSecurity from hash preimage resistanceSPHINCS+‚ÄúDigital signatures built purely from hashes‚ÄùIsogeny-basedStructure of elliptic curves and their mappingsSIKE (broken in 2022)‚ÄúPaths between geometric shapes‚Äù
Objective of this lecture‚Ä¢Not for math understanding and theore1cal depth.‚Ä¢But for future implementa1on and applica1on of QPC in your professional works and research.
Polynomial Ring with a Modulus: Used in Kyber
Review class & quiz 3‚Ä¢Monday (Dec. 1) after Thanksgiving. ‚Ä¢Content: Chapter 4 (excluding PQC)‚Ä¢No class on Dec. 3 (Wednesday)
